title: What happens when you max out credit cards?
question: My aunt and uncle recently retired with good credit scores/histories. They owned 2 homes, but after selling one with large equity to pay off their other home during their retirement process, they changed the title of their paid-off home, so their son now is the only one on the title of that home. Both relatives don't have any assets at this moment and are living in their same house that's now owned by their son. They maxed out their credit cards worth of $300K, because my aunt said that it gradually went down the spiral for them as they found themselves striped of money that they used to make when they worked, so they didn't stop spending for a while and basically ended up with tons of debt that they can't pay. Their son helped them with the minimum payments for a few months, but he's no
answers:
Please note the correct responses posted by Mr. Daymude and Mr. Chen. Transferring title to a house with a large amount of equity, without any consideration (payment) for that transfer, can be a fraudulent transfer. Since transfer of title is a public record, it will not be a secret from the creditors. The transfer also has the effect of leaving them without a homestead exemption, which would be $175k if either your aunt or uncle are seniors (65 or older). The best course of action at this point is to immediately consult with experienced bankruptcy attorneys to see whether another transfer back to their names is possible, followed by a bankruptcy.

If a bankruptcy case is not possible then they would eventually be sued. Some credit card companies sue directly and others sell the debt to debt buyers. They would want to hire a consumer attorney to defend each lawsuit and settle them (or get dismissals). At some point it might be necessary to take equity out of the house to pay for this. When four years have passed since they defaulted on the credit cards, the statute of limitations will have run, and that will provide a way to avoid any further judgments.
They need to look at filing bankruptcy. Unless they ran up the credit cards on purpose, there should be relief.

They wouldn't be arrested for excessive debt. There will likely be a multitude of collection lawsuits on the unpaid credit cards which will eventually result in civil money judgments. As Attorney Daymude indicated, they would not be entitled to the homestead exemption if they transferred title to their son. Another point, depending on the facts, is that they might be sued for fraudulent transfer (fraudulent conveyance). In California, a claim for "fraudulent transfer" is authorized by the Fraudulent Transfer Act, which is enacted at California Civil Code sections 3439 to 3439.12. Under Section 3439.04, a transfer is fraudulent as to a creditor, whether the creditor's claim arose before or after the transfer was made or the obligation was incurred, if the debtor made the transfer or incurred the obligation as follows:

1) With actual intent to hinder, delay, or defraud any creditor of the debtor.

2) Without receiving a reasonably equivalent value in exchange for the transfer or obligation, and the debtor either:

A) Was engaged or was about to engage in a business or a transaction for which the remaining assets of the debtor were unreasonably small in relation to the business or transaction.

B) Intended to incur, or believed or reasonably should have believed that he or she would incur, debts beyond his or her ability to pay as they became due. The purpose of California's Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (Civil Code sections 3439–3439.12) is "to prevent debtors from placing property which legitimately should be available for the satisfaction of demands of creditors beyond their reach...." (Chichester v. Mason (1941) 43 Cal.App.2d 577, 584.)

Unfortunately, for your aunt and uncle, merely transferring title to their son will not save the home from the reach of their creditors under the facts you have alleged. And, as an added problem, they no longer can claim a homestead exemption in the house since they no longer own it.

The best advice I can give you, to give to your aunt and uncle, is for them to promptly consult qualified bankruptcy counsel. They may be able to undo what they should not have done so that, if BK is required, they will receive the most debt relief.

An aggressive creditor can cause them a lot of emotional and financial pain. This type of self-help “debt protection” is fraught with unintended bad consequences.
